Authors: S. I. Warwick, Connie A Sauder, Ihsan Al-Shehbaz
Title:
Systematic position of Ivania, Scoliaxon, and Phravenia
(Brassicaceae)
Keywords:
Brassicaceae, ITS phylogeny, tribal assignments, Ivania,
Scoliaxon, Phravenia, Scoliaxoneae.
Abstract:
Sequence data from the ribosomal internal transcribed
spacer (ITS) region were used to determine the tribal placement of the
previously unassigned genera Ivania, Scoliaxon, and Phravenia (gen.
nov.). The ITS-based phylogenetic tribal backbone of Brassicaceae was
used to determine the position of these three genera in relation to the
44 recognized tribes in the family. Scoliaxon, although showing
remarkable morphological similarities to Asta (Asteae), formed an
independent clade with 100% bootstrap (BS) support in the tribal
analysis, whereas both Ivania and Phravenia clustered with the
Thelypodieae clade (96% BS support). In a second and more comprehensive
analysis of the Thelypodieae, both species of Ivania formed a clade with
61% BS support within the tribe and were affiliated to other
Thelypodieae genera from the Southern Hemisphere. The monospecific
Phravenia formed a clade with 74% bootstrap support within the
Thelypodieae, and its species did not resolve with Dryopetalon or Sibara
in which it had been previously assigned. The present findings support
the placement of Ivania and Phravenia in the Thelypodieae, as well as
the recognition of the new genus Phravenia and new tribe Scoliaxoneae,
both of which are formally described herein.
